Definition: Toxicity is defined as something that makes someone want to quit a conversation because it is harsh, insulting, or unfair. You must sort the input statement into one of two categories: Toxic and Non-toxic.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Comment: " act as though they are doing charity work when we are paying more than their mortgage, taxes, insurance, and then some"

Give me a break. Who is acting like it is a charity? It is an exchange with different risks/values for both parties. As a renter you didn't have to work to come up with the 20% or more down payment on the property. You don't have to foot the bill for maintenance and systems replacement, which averages roughly $2k/yr on the typical Portland bungalow, but can spike when you need a new roof, plumbing, water heater, etc. You don't run the risk of losing all of your equity in an earthquake, fire, or other disaster. You don't run the risk of losing all your equity if a payment is missed and the bank decides to foreclose. You get to forego all of that risk, commitment, and work, put it on the back of the landlord, and then you expect a permanent right to reside in their property at a fixed rate you choose? And you say this isn't a sense of entitlement on your part? Hah!

Comment: I have been reading about this for years and have provided my objective, factual sources. So here goes.  I'll walk you through this one source.  http://sports.usatoday.com/ncaa/finances/
- CSU is #71.

- Under revenues for 2016 you will see student fees at $5.7 million and school subsidy at 16.5 million - so over $22 million subsidy from academics

- donations were all of $3.3 million

Comment: As others making comments here have already noted, Cannabis is already widely (albeit illegally) consumed & a major traffic & worksite safety concern. Reducing the dangers entailed is indeed an important public safety objective but delaying legalization or aggressively limiting the circumstances for legal purchase & consumption of Cannabis from licensed vendors is, therefore, both misguided & counterproductive. 

The same applies to measures to aggressively cap buzz available or up the price of product available legally as this will only undercut the capacity of the legally available product to complete with product trafficked by organized crime. 

In short, we need to think clearly about the public policy goals we can and should achieve & avoid confused attempts to somehow both legalize but suppress the marketing & consumption of Pot.

Comment: No one here is robbing the poor to get rich, including Buffett. I disagree with Buffett that the way to tax fairly is to raise tax rates on the rich, while leaving lots of loopholes for people like Buffett to avoid paying those taxes at all. He is being self serving in suggesting such a thing, while only sounding like a liberal. Instead, get rid of all loopholes and have a single flat tax rate with a higher income floor under which no taxes are due. This way, the poor who are struggling pay no tax, the middle class pay a tax they can afford, and the rich pay lots of taxes as they earn more. Tax capital gains at full income rate, but only when they are pulled out of the investments market thus encouraging people to invest, thus creating more jobs, plus allowing people to save for retirement.

Kleptocrats like Putin etc. are a whole different deal, and not the way to run a country.

Comment: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) just released their EV infrastructure analysis. (https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy17osti/69031.pdf)

The NREL found that a fleet of 15 million EVs would need 400 corridor DCFC stations (2,500 plugs) spaced 70 miles apart across the U.S. Interstate Highway System. 

"Results suggest that relatively few corridor DCFC stations could enable long-distance BEV travel between U.S. cities, where vehicles are concentrated. Under most scenarios, the number of required stations is similar to the number of corridor DCFC stations already established by Tesla or the number planned by Electrify America within the next two years."

Comment: Thank you Mr. Erickson,
Your prediction of the state's economy shrinking is spot on. The state has ghost towns abound that powered Alaska's economy. The Last Train to Nowhere and Kennecott are sobering reminders of what TAPS may likely look like: albeit we pray in our children's lifetime, not ours.
I'm troubled with so many Alaskans forfeiting their PFD to the IRS for unpaid taxes, CSED for progeny unsupported and Municipalities/Court System for fines and tickets unpaid. In that order are the 3 largest recipients of our PFD deposits.
I admit our family's PFD's went to foolhardy expenses such as college and orthodontics, but darn it, how do we replace the $8 billion/yr that used to gush out of the ground? No gold revenues, no fish fees, no lumber surcharges, no sales/income taxes, no Raid on the Permanent Fund will ever replace that. If we skim $8 billion/yr from the Perm Fund it'll be drained in 7 years. Skimming 3% saves the corpus, yet starves the poor IRS, CSED and Muni/Courts.

Comment: What do you mean by 'capital gains are taxable to the U.S.??

If you hold a dividend paying U.S. stock in a TFSA, the dividends are subject to U.S. withholding tax and this is not recoverable (it is recoverable for most taxpayers in a non-registered account via the Foreign Tax Credit). However, any capital gains on a U.S. stock in a TFSA are not subject to either Canadian or U.S. capital gains taxes.

Nazism on the other hand set out to conquer the entire world into Hitler's "empire of a thousand years" - and came damn close to succeeding.

Communists today tend to advocate democratic rather than revolutionary change. Nazis still advocate change by genocide.

Nazism arose in a free country. Soviet style communism only ever arose in countries that had never been free to begin with.

Comment: It is really simple.  The athletic department should support academic success.  As far as that goes, the ski team has always been one of the jewels of the athletic department, but even the ski team has a travel budget that makes little sense.  Can you imagine what an impressive intramural program could be had for 25% of the athletic department budget?  We would have club teams with coaches.  We would have tourna,nets between the best UAA and UAF basketball teams.  We would train professional quality referees and we would have workshops for intramural coaches.

It could be a revolutionary awesome program.  Instead we hand out scholarships to a bunch of Canucks.  I love the boys, and I love watching the Nanooks beat the Seawolves, but we have lost sight on the point of the whole thing.

A travel budget is not needed to support elite skiers in Alaska.  They are already where they need to be.  Keep the program and tell the NCAA to get wet.  That's my solution.

Comment: John - I'd be interested in your views on how public support of resource management plays a role. Unlike fish, game animals are easily observable. The chance to view critters in their natural environment aligns the wildlife viewing (non-eaters) constituency with the hunting constituency in support of political and financial habitat preservation efforts.  Efforts like this saved the Mississippi flyway.

Fish are very different.  With the exception of spawning salmon, they are not easily observable, they don't have big brown eyes, and they don't bear adorable young.  In short, far fewer non-eaters are going to rally to support efforts to preserve their habitat.  The practical result would be more development in riparian areas and much looser regulations on water use and quality.  

So I hear what you're saying, but fear you'd be dooming the very fish you seek to protect.  There's a lot of good gravel in the Kenai River and Paxon Lake, and the DOT has a lot of projects . . . .

Comment: I don't understand your "difference" between being forced to provide service in a restaurant and being forced to bake a cake.  To those who owned and worked in the segregated restaurants, they were, indeed, being forced by civil rights laws to serve those they did not believe should be eating with white folks.  

I think the laws that keep the public market places open to all are very important laws.  Perhaps I think that because I grew up in one of those Southern states while and where segregation was an accepted way of life; and remnants of that attitude still exist.  Everyone agreed on it in times past - all the white butchers, bakers, and candlestick makers agreed that they would not sell to blacks or only sell to them out the back door.  Social pressure to conform can be as bad as it can be good.  

Do we want the Christian version of Sharia or can there be a common ground where people of different beliefs can respect each other and share space to buy and sell goods?

Comment: As you say, putting alcoholics on no-alcohol conditions is a useless and self-defeating practice. For that reason, many prosecutors are reluctant to ask for no-alcohol conditions, and many judges are reluctant to impose them. Unfortunately "many" is not "all". Further, the vast majority of people who are released on bail are released by the police without ever seeing a judge. I can't speak for provincial or municipal police forces, but the RCMP has a non-discretionary policy of requiring no-alcohol conditions in every case in which alcohol was involved.

This needs to change. In general, bail orders should not have no-alcohol conditions, and there should be clear directions from the appropriate cabinet ministers to all police and prosecutors not to ask for them. In those cases where alcohol is clearly an issue, courts will often impose a condition that "you must not be found outside your residence under the influence of alcohol". That is a condition that can be complied with.

Comment: Gee, St. Ambrose was a catechumen [not even baptized], when the people selected [voted for him] to be their bishop.  Augustine was a layman, when he was selected to be a bishop.
It was the selection by the COMMUNITY that gave this power and authority to the person selected as the leader of a particular community of people---in a town or a part of a town.

In a time even earlier than that, people selected their own presbyters [presiders] to celebrate the Meal [the Mass as we call it today].  Were they ordained?  NO!  But the people were Christians and they gathered together in Jesus' name to "do this in memory of him".

We are and will be going back to this situation again as there are fewer and fewer priests.  And Jesus will be in the midst of these people as he had been in the early centuries of Christianity----in the deserts and in the catacombs.

Comment: OK, Ms. Brown, I'll take your bait.  I've lived in Anchorage for the past 49 years and over that time I have, indeed, watched the trees.  This year the trees leafed out about three weeks earlier than normal.  Timberline has also increased over 100 feet in elevation over the course of the past 49 years.  The trees are also dropping their leaves later in the year than they used to.  And I've noted that the fire season starts about a month earlier than it used to.  Yes, one can, indeed, learn a lot by observing the trees.

Comment: "No, in 1991, the people of Crimea, along with a majority of the other people of Ukraine, voted to leave the USSR and form an independent Ukrainian nation."
Here's a history lesson for you, TDM: There were multiple referendums in 1991 in the former Ukrainian region. One in January was as I said:
"In 1991, Crimea voted 94.3% in favour to leave Ukraine and become an autonomous republic of the USSR."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_sovereignty_referendum,_1991
It was only because the USSR then dissolved that Crimea defaulted on that referendum's outcome and instead became an autonomous region within Ukraine. Crimeans have never wanted to be a part of Ukraine, and they voted accordingly in 2014, in the referendum organized by their own democratically-elected government.

Electricity is a good and service that is supposed to be paid for - the more you consume, the more you pay for the goods that you consume.

Comment: Wow DP. What a gross misrepresentation of the facts! There are so many errors and lies in this article. Let's cut to the chase here. Working for the State of Colorado is no panacea. Comment: Although I disagree with some of the sentiments expressed in this piece by this fine writer, I do agree that Native Alaskans should hold on furiously to their culture, as should all peoples who live in places dominated by foreign culture, because if they don't, those foreign cultures will supplant their own. I am an American of Irish descent, and I appreciate the de-anglicization of place names in Ireland and the regrowth of the Irish language there. But, let's recognize that the domination of one culture over another is not unique to the Americas and not unique to the time of European dominance in world affairs. The Chinese dominated Vietnam for over a century, as they now dominate Tibet. Arabs, Berbers, and Turks dominated much of southern Europe for centuries. There are many, many more examples of the same. In fact, the view that only Europeans and their descendants engage in cultural domination is itself a result of ethnocentrism and its dehumanizing "noble savage" fantasy.

Comment: I agree, especially the family comment.  In the old days, family took care of each other.  If, for whatever reason, a family member lost his/her home, you could be sure that another family member would welcome him/her.  Times are changing and, the family structure is slowly eroding.  Not trying to bring race into this, but Filipino people are trying to do their best to hold families together.  We might joke about "Filipino mansions," those older homes with 7-8 additions/bedrooms but think about it.  If the house only housed one family, the other 2-3 would be on the street.  We actually have a 4 bedroom home across the street from us that houses THREE families because our community is strict on building additions.  I blame modern technology such as computers, smart TV's and smart phones for taking away family time.  I remember playing cards and board games with mom and dad as kids.  Try doing that with your kids today!

Comment: This is going to sting. 

I promise you, no matter what "solution" they come up with it will have nothing to do with what is good for the Canadian population. This will be about saving the banks, and of the little people are going to take it in the teeth.

The banks cannot take these assets just reverting back to normal market prices. It's not just the price of the property anymore, they've been used as leverage for huge financial instruments, and if property plunges in price the asset to liability ratio becomes very, very sad. That's double-plus bad for banks.

If it gets bad enough, the banks will enact their bail-in legislation. That'll let them take money from their creditors, and help out their books.  The creditors are you. If you have a bank account, you are a creditor. You don't even have to own property in those markets to take part in this game.

Comment: JC,

That is not a very good analogy. For one, you don't actually possess the right to have a lawful society, thought you do benefit from one in Canada. Second, a common test placed on ones freedom to act in society without hindrance is the harm principle. Using this test, one can can clearly establish that those who exceed the speed limit are more likely to cause accidents that could physically and demonstrably harm others. Therefore, they are prohibited from doing so by the law. Ones unwillingness to use another individuals desired pronoun or support their chosen way of life does not sufficiently harm the other in a demonstrable fashion. Hurt feelings is not enough to meet the harm principle test or we'd be in a world of problems as everyone would be before the court for hurting others feelings one way or another. One should have the right to their chosen gender identity, no question, but that right need not require others to do anything but not impede their choice.

Comment: The Danish Meteorological Institute reports that Greenland’s ice sheet has seen more growth so far this year than in the last four years. Greenland’s growth in 2015 is also higher than the mean growth for 1990 to 2011.
“The Antarctic is actually growing and all the evidence in the last few months suggests many assumptions about the poles was wrong,” Dr. Benny Peiser, director of the Global Warming Policy Forum, told the U.K. Express.

“Global sea ice is at a record high, another key indicator that something is working in the opposite direction of what was predicted,” Peiser said. “Most people think the poles are melting… they’re not. This is a huge inconvenience that reality is now catching up with climate alarmists, who were predicting that the poles would be melting fairly soon.”

Read more: http://dailycaller.com/2015/01/13/wrong-again-greenlands-ice-sheet-defies-critics-with-4-year-high/#ixzz4JLG8yMYP

Comment: Actually, no, any one who pursues it of most Puget Sound counties can find out exact amount paid, and exact amounts allocated for various categories, such as "LAKE STEVENS SCHOOL DIST NO 4", one I'm looking at for someone in Lake Stevens next to the Lake itself. This person pays $2,281.21 to schools, part of $6,085.57 overall.
In my post above I provided SnoCo's links for doing that. Use the "Select City" dropdown, then an area of the map with the pointer, and the keep clicking the map until the parcel numbers show.
Then, enter parcel number into a spot on the Assessor page, from the link, and you'll get a page with payment histories, and current breakdowns for this year. For some you can click on the page in a spot for a picture of the house.
It's a good way to while away the day. Absolutely fascinating.
King County has a great one too, and you can find out a lot about the very rich and famous. Find it at: http://gismaps.kingcounty.gov/parcelviewer2/
Look up your landlord's! :)
Enjoy!

Comment: I've lived for over 40 years close in to the city center. When my wife and I owned a software business, we walked to our offices downtown. We put very few miles on our vehicles.

With that out of the way, here's a problem in Eugene -- bicycling issues have become "religious" issues, rather than pragmatic quality-of-life issues.

Among the dysfunctional outcomes is low priority for pedestrians or even degradation of the safety and appeal of walking.

The south Willamette Street reconfiguration is an extreme -- and glaringly obvious -- example.

Driving down the new layout, try to visualize how different the result would have been if -- instead of still hazardous, unappealing and unnecessary bike lanes, the same amount of right of way had been transformed into a parking strip (not for parking) with landscaping and trees separating and shading the sidewalk.

There's all this outcry to turn that area into a "20-minute" neighborhood, which it actually already is.

Comment: There's been discussion of this issue elsewhere on social media such that I think it warrants further discussion here.
I think it's encumbent upon all citizens -- including elected officials -- to speak their minds in the face of power gone wrong. I also think it is the responsibility of elected officials to protect their constituents -- all of whom may not agree with them -- from adverse impacts that may result from their official actions. 
When I led the City in forming a resolution in support of marriage equality a few years ago, I knew there would be no adverse impact upon the citizens who didn't not agree with my position on that matter. In the case of a sanctuary city resolution, there is a strong chance that a vindictive President and Att'y General would take action against a relatively defenseless city such as ours. I would favor a petition signed by every willing elected official and and every citizen in favor be sent to the President. I would sign it in a New York minute.

Comment: Didn't Toronto remove it's bicycle lanes?

E-bikes use the same batteries as the Tesla electric cars, unlike the Tesla, E-bikes do not heavily burden your already over-stressed power grid. Get with times Ontario, E-bikes are THE most environmentally-friendly modes of powered transportation. Many folks don't ride a bicycle to work simply because they don't want arrive to work exhausted sweaty. Others simply can't ride due to the sheer distance or their own physical limitations. 

Europe is experiencing an explosion of E-bikes, almost all regions are embracing them. Many urban areas of Europe are planning for zero emissions in the very near future. E-bikes are large part of that plan. 

Just like cars, safety is controlled by the operater, not the machine. Instead of "putting the brakes on E-bikes", why not work towards a safe way to incorporate them as an alternative model of transportation.

Every E-bike, means one less car on the road sitting in a traffic jam.

Comment: Plenty of wells in the LA Basin that will build up to over 1,000 lbs of tubing pressure and similar with casing pressure. The downhole pressure anywhere in the 500 sq mile basin will vary considerably due to incredible geologic forces. Generally, we can estimate reservoir pressure by dividing in half the length of a typical 8 5/8ths casing. So 10,000' well would have around 5,000 lbs of downhole pressure, and when that gets depleted, recovery starts to go down rapidly. The tar pits are a surface expression, just like when Col Hancock had a lake of oil in his lower 40 before mid Wilshire was developed. However, wells in Rosecrans go down easily to 10,000'. Remember, the LA Basin has over 27,000' of sandstone depositions that were sourced by nodular shale real deep. It is also considered to have more oil per square meter than any other basin on the planet. Back to your comment, while some fields have been pressure depleted, that does not mean there is no significant pressures still.

Comment: Scott, very informative article.

It shows the difficulty in futures trading.  You need to get both the direction and the timing correct.  It looks to me that if the price is currently being driven by the futures market as you indicate, than this means that we should eventually see the price of oil increase to reflect supply/demand balance.  The investment in production has been much lower the past 2 years as the price of oil has been declining.  Eventually this will have a large impact on world production and with demand on a steady but slow upward climb, inventories will drop.  I see US shale being able to fill some of this void with fairly quick turnaround, but it won't be able to make up all production that is being lost, especially in those long time frame and expensive deep water wells.

This seems to me like a good opportunity to pick up some solid low cost, well financed producers that have seen stock prices driven down due to concern about the recent drop in oil prices.

Alaska is full of stories...yours is particularly poignant.

In ''78  I graduated from college  and  joined the Jesuit Volunteer Corp.

Comment: North America doesn't have to make a "substantial investment in rail" for rail to thrive. We simply need to charge truckers the true cost of their use of the taxpayer paid for roads. 

A single transport truck causes in the range of 70,000 times the damage to a highway as it passes over it as does a typical car. In effect, our highways degrade because of trucks.  Yet we continue to allow unfettered use of the public roads while forcing the rails to maintain their own system with relatively little support. If more people understood this, we would charge trucking firms something closer to the true cost, making the use of rail far more attractive for the movement of goods.

Comment: Democrats ought to form a movement to counter the Tea Party, which is largely a Know-Nothing movement. I'd recommend the Mayflower Compact. While the historic Tea Party saw disgruntled merchants dump a cargo of tea into Boston Harbour rather than pay a new tax on it and tried to blame the vandalism on a local First Nation, the Mayflower Compact actually took the concept of government seriously. It's a short document, but the core of it reads: "[the signers] covenant and combine ourselves together into a civil body politic; for our better ordering, and preservation and furtherance of the ends aforesaid; and by virtue hereof to enact, constitute, and frame, such just and equal laws, ordinances, acts, constitutions, and offices, from time to time, as shall be thought most meet and convenient for the general good of the colony; unto which we promise all due submission and obedience."

I'm sick of libertarian Republicans whose Me First attitude undermines democratic liberties and equality.

That same day one of the stolen cards was used at Carrs, Carrs security had them on video and knew who they were as regulars at that store and called APD. APD arrived to pick up the video as evidence, while at the same time the thief stopped by the Carrs and APD was able to "talk" with them right then and there, but no arrest over the stolen guns (a felony) because the  officer didn't know the two cases were linked to the same theft. Dispatch later told me the two cases were on different unlinked computer systems. Comment: I was born after VII and missed the worst of your experience.  However, my first few years in the Church (as an adult convert) involved this merit based salvation, then after a few years of trying to be the perfect Catholic, constantly feeling guilty and fretting about not being good enough for God, my moment of transformative grace came in surrender to the reality that I am a failure...and God loves me that way.  The freedom of not having to be perfect has energized my spiritual life and love for God in a way that perfection never could have.  I now understand St. Paul when he says "the letter of the law kills, but the spirit gives life."  I think (I am riffing on Richard Rohr here) that strict, rule based, merit based religion is a necessary stage of growth on the way to spiritual adulthood.  Some people mistake an adolescent spiritual rebellion for real freedom, others take the opposite tack and are so afraid of rebellion that they never grow to adulthood.

Comment: Not true, Klastri, not true.  DACA has been challenged.  You might want to check Texas vs United States.  In February 2015, a U.S. District Judge in Texas issued a preliminary injunction against DACA.  The Obama administration appealed to the Fifth U.S, Circuit Court of Appeals, which, in November 2015, a three-judge panel ruled against the Obama administration by upholding the lower court’s injunction against DACA and another program created by Obama, called Deferred Action for Parents of Americans.   The Obama Administration then appealed to the Supreme Court.  On June 23, 2016, the Supreme Court announced it had deadlocked 4-4 in a decision that left in place the lower court’s preliminary injunction blocking the program.  A petition for rehearing filed by the Obama administration was denied by the court on October 3, 2016.   http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/united-states-v-texas/

Comment: The SQ--a major Quebec police organization does the obvious--and I applaud it.  In addition to "reassessing" the way it conducts initial sexual assault investigations, it has decided that hundreds of previous cases will be reclassified as "unsolved" instead of "unfounded."

It's a step in the right direction. Merely semantics? Mas, non! 
It's important:   it eliminates the suggestion that complainants involved  made trivial or false or complaints.  I.e.: no judgement call.  Just not enough evidence to go forward, so...case remains "unsolved."  

Are advocacy groups satisfied?  No. One group's goal: encourage more women to come forward with complaints.  And this word change, they argue, won't do that.  Too bad: that's NOT the job of police forces.  That's the ADVOCATES' job.  

Getting back to semantics, however: police "dodged the bullet" so to speak.  "unsolved" presupposes that each of these files represents a case worth pursuing.  Better label: "No action--lack of evidence."

Comment: Lars Bauer wrote: "And when they've done that to us (twice, in our experience); we happily take the $500 voucher (which is a generous offer, since they are under NO obligation to do that), go to the lounge, pour a cold one, and wait for the next flight."
.
Actually Lars, depending on where you are going the carrier is probably getting off cheap by giving you a voucher.  If you don't get to your destination in less than two hours of the scheduled time the carrier owes you the cost of a one-way ticket x2 and you get to keep your original ticket.  If it's more than 2 hours the carrier owes you the one way fare to your destination x4 - and you get to keep your original ticket.  See:
http://www.kfdi.com/news/national/passangers-rights-federal-laws-allow-for-overbooking

Comment: CE:  the only thing better than having a hundred acre "woodlot" is having a buddy with a 100 acre woodlot.  we bought stumpage from a friend who had a large pasture near Blachley...low ground, hence a huge ash grove.  best firewood in the world...straight grained, and about the only hardwood which you can burn green...we, over 15-20 years, cut hundreds of cords.  started at $3/cord stumpage....last year we were paying $20/cord...Of course, delivered firewood went from $25/cord to $120/cord over that same period of time. Comment: Perhaps you are misunderstand me:

In the Old Testament, the death penalty was used liberally and God did command the deaths of people.  In the New Testament, we do not see this.  This has lead people to jump to conclusions and claim that the God of the OT and the NT God must be two different gods, etc.  

I don't see it that way--but my position is not that God is commanding us to use the death penalty.  My position is that the death penalty can be morally justifiable in certain cases.  We are commanded to love, indeed.  God is, indeed love.  However---love of enemies must be balanced by the need to protect society as well as bring some semblance of justice to the victims of horrific crimes.  

You don't mean to tell me that you believe that Osama Bin Laden should not have been put to death do you?  You don't mean to tell me that God holds us in contempt for putting him to death, do you?

Comment: Kudos to the government for taking on the issue which is contentious politically. Corporate tax rates were significantly reduced by previous conservatives, resulting in many individuals setting up CCPC's for "businesses" for tax benefits only. However, there needs to be a delicate scalpel approach and not the crude axe, as the lion's share of CCPC's are legitimate businesses who use the benefits for (arm's length) hiring, investing in plant & equipment, new tools, expanding revenue sources, etc. High earning professionals who already have high T4 income (ie. MP's, university professors, some IT employees) set up corporations for  "side" businesses (ie speaking engagements, contract work on the side). Where is the business risk in this?  These income streams should be reported as other income/sole proprietorship income on the T1 return. And their retirement investments 
(registered and non-registered) should be subject to the same rules as employees and reported on the T1 return.

Comment: The definition of what is "Indian Country" and where the limits of its Constitutionally-ensured sovereignty end is not as cut and dried as "physical borders," particularly when it involves non-tribal members. Thus this bit in the story: 

"The state attorney general's office has no specific policy or guidance on banishments. Generally "banishment orders can present difficult constitutional issues that have to evaluated on a case by case basis," said Cori Mills, an assistant attorney general."

Particularly here in Alaska where, due to the essential lack of treaty-defined reservation lands, the limits of that Sovereignty will often be real but intangible. We are creating and adapting law to fit changing circumstances.

In any event, banishment has a long history as a punishment even in "white" American history, communal beliefs on what punishments are "reasonable" impositions on Rights, and thus Constitutional, and what level of due process may apply, are always open to debate.

Comment: It is accurate to say that Alberta pays in far more than it gets from the federal government for a wide variety of reasons, including demographics, earnings etc. However, what is avoided in all these discussions, perhaps because it is too politically sensitive, is the fact that equalization is a major factor in allowing provinces like Prince Edward Island to exist. It is foolish to have four separate provinces in the east. Yes, loyalties to provinces run deep there, but it would make sense if leaders in those provinces would at least begin to consider some sharing of services, if not outright amalgamation. In particular, Prince Edward Island, as a province of just 146,000 people, should be sharing many provincial services with New Brunswick, Nova Scotia or both, to reduce the bureaucratic and administrative costs of government. Then equalization payments would be used more effectively.

Comment: I attempted Capitol 33 years ago with a friend who was a serious international mountaineer.   The rock on this peak is some of the worst of the Elks, rocks the size of refrigerators completely unattached along the Knife Edge and starting to slide toward oblivion the minute you place a foot on them.  I imagine 30 years of climbers have knocked down some of the worst, but the entire peak is rotten to the core.  From mid Knife edge, we watched two ahead of us spidermanning up the normal main route to the final ridge.  100 feet below that section of the "trail" the precipice drops vertical for hundreds of feet (you angle out to the left to get on this section of "trail").  A patch of loose rack, about thirty feet by thirty feet, it all started a slow slide as one giant agglommeration,  like a giant piece of internal onion  skin with them plastered on it.  Rope might help? No, everything that could be roped to was sliding as a oner.  After it all sliding down about 6 feet, it stopped.

Comment: The "institutional Church" is a real thing.

Sociologists divide organizations into two types, the Gesellschaft and the Gemeinschaft (it was obviously a German sociologist who came up with these terms). A Gesellschaft is a formal organization, with officers, written rules, etc. A Gemeinschaft is an informal organization.  The Catholic Church is both a Gesellschaft and a Gemeinschaft. The institutional Church is the Gesellschaft, but the Gemeinschaft is the Body of Christ.

Comment: Using fairness to "rate" tax plans problematic. With annual deficits of about $500 billion and a $20 trillion national debt, the only discussion I see a need for is how to increase revenue and decrease spending.
.
Since the middle class and poor don't have much money and considering taxes at all levels (not just federal income taxes) can't contribute significant federal revenue then increasing revenue substantially must come from the rich. 
.
Decreasing spending though is more problematic when fairness is considered. As 67% of federal spending is on entitlement programs decreasing spending must consider these federal programs.
.
If somehow both could be accomplished and (miracle!) an annual federal surplus of $500 billion was achieved, it would take more than 40 years to pay down the national debt.
.
Fairness should be less of a priority than reality.

Comment: The reason for the dominance of Ontario and Quebec is because we have a larger population - there are exceptions PEI has 4 seats and a population smaller than the town I live in an only has 1 seat.

The seats in the HC are mostly apportioned based on Population - so as an area grows riding's are realigned or seats are added.  The point of the electoral college in the US is to elect the President, something similar here would not work as we do not directly elect the Prime Minster.  

The leader of party winning the most seats gets to be PM. For the Electoral college to be similar to Canada we would either have to vote a second time for PM or the majority of the Congress and Senate in the US would have to chose the President.

BTW the Senate was supposed to account for regional differences with smaller Population provinces being guaranteed a minimum number of senators

Comment: An employer has already investigated the facts whenever a nurse is disciplined, and more so when one is fired.  Charts are scrutinized and witnesses are questioned.  It's the results of that investigation which are sent to the CNO.  

If a nurse contests the facts alleged by the employer, the College investigates.  If he or she agrees, no they don't - unless the report is deficient on its face.  The person reporting on behalf of the employer is usually an advanced degree nurse-manager close to the situation, and the CNO relies on that.

There is no reason to suspect - even now - that the medication errors Wettlaufer made and was disciplined for were anything but errors.  If the patients involved in those instances died, we'd know about it. 

What I think you're talking about is investigating every patient, every chart, that a terminated nurse has ever been involved with. That's unrealistitic.  And there are 1300 terminations a year.

Comment: It's actually not an "archaic" system at all.  It's doing exactly what it is supposed to do - namely keeping the island community intact and safe from Bay Street execs, house flippers, and other profiteers.
It works perfectly.

The community over there is vibrant and alive - and most of all, it's affordable to the folks who grew up there - unlike the rest of Toronto.

The prices aren't what the article says.  They basically work out to what it would cost to build the house today, minus depreciation.  So, if you keep your house repaired, and make improvements, that value is maintained.  You loose nothing.  

It is, however, not at all suitable for flippers, speculators, and profiteers - which is perfect, imho.  None of those people know the first thing about living in a community. 

 If you buy a house there it's because you want to live there - not because you're trying to extract profit.

Comment: Sorry, but Dale is right.  I'm a frequent flyer out of Bethel and I've spoken with many pilots, the problem with Hageland is a cultural one, their culture is one of cut-thought competition: the pilots who "get it done" get more flight hours.  This culture pushes pilots to take unnecessary risks.

I was on a Grant flight 3 weeks ago trying to reach our destination ahead of storm, even though we were only a couple miles out from our destination we turned back when the local AWOS started reporting winds over minimums.  When I got to my destination the next day I was talking to some folks who it turned out landed on a Hageland flight that flew into the storm shortly after we turned back.  They told me that the landing was hairy and then the pilot refused to taxi on to the apron for fear of turning his aircraft into a sustained high crosswind, he dumped passengers and gear at the runway exit and made a rapid departure .  You call this the actions of a careful and professional pilot?

Comment: Reform HIPAA, and create a national database accessible to professional mental health providers, and limited readability by the FBI background check system. If a professional, board-certified doctor believes a patient to be a danger to himself or others with a weapon, they add a flag to prevent purchase of new weapons. The flag has to be validated by a second, independent evaluation from another professional board-certified doctor. The patient may petition for the removal of the flag at any time by submitting to a case-review. Flags automatically expire after 2 years unless renewed based on evidence. Whole system is subject to medical ethics laws and standards under the American Medical Association.

This would allow diagnosed patients within a narrow scope, meeting clinical standards to be barred from new purchases, would remove government whims from the process, and prevent law enforcement from directly accessing a "database of gun owners".

Comment: Tactics of Rebuttal: The 4D Approach

Russia’s narrative can be viewed as an offensive weapon.  When it comes to defending Russia, different tactics are used. They can be summed up in four words: dismiss, distort, distract, dismay.

Dismiss: The first Russian approach to negative reporting or comment is to dismiss it, either by denying the allegations on the ground, or denigrating the one who makes them.

Distort: Russian officials and media have also developed a strong tendency to distort information to serve their overall narrative.

Distract: A further tool in Russia’s information arsenal is distraction: turning attention away from the activities of Russia and its allies by launching accusations elsewhere.

Dismay: The final key tool in Russia’s communications arsenal is to spread dismay, by warning that moves which Russia opposes will have disastrous consequences for those planning them.

It’s a brand of information warfare, known as dezinformatsiya.

Comment: "The system has worked in states with smaller populations than Alaska, but not here. In 1998, the Legislature passed a poison-pill law that requires managed care organizations to allow members to see any doctor they choose, defeating the central concept."

I take care of myself, so see a doctor rarely enough that I don't really care if I see the same one all the time, but in the managed care system that he's advocating, you have no choice. You'll see whatever doctor is up on rotation, which leads to inconsistent care, constantly changing meds and no actual treatment plan.

Wohlforth makes the mistake of thinking that medical care itself is more important than good medical care ... and, yes, there is a huge difference. Healthy people like me can see any doctor and take care of the occasional sinus infection and sprained ankle, but when someone has a condition, consistency matters and the system Wohlforth describes is inherently inconsistent. People aren't cattle. They deserve better.

Comment: A brief history to provide some perspective:
McCormick Pier was the first substantial project leading to the conversion of the industrial area north of Burnside, resulting in the creation of what is now called The Pearl District. It is the root of The Pearl’s trunk.
In 1979, the Bill Naito Co. acquired the property from Union Pacific. Bill Naito was widely recognized for taking on ventures that were at least as beneficial to the community as they were potentially moneymaking. In 1981 he built the 300-unit McCormick Pier Apartments along the waterfront, replacing a derelict warehouse district and providing needed middle-income housing in an area where other developers had concluded it could not succeed.
The company sold the property in 2002 to a developer who successfully converted the apartments into condominiums. 
Naito Parkway is named for a responsible developer who had a great influence on Portland’s growth into a unique and desirable city.

Comment: RE: "competition across state lines". Insurance companies already can sell to states other than the one they are headquartered in. Premera is based in Washington, for example. Today, companies have to comply with Federal laws, as well as the laws of the state they are selling in. When we combine "return the power to the States" with "across State lines", after the dust clears we will see one or two States which will have the least restrictions on what insurance companies can do, in return for the tax and licensing income. That is exactly why most all credit cards are regulated under the laws of either Delaware or South Dakota. Those two states have the least restrictions and regulations. Other states can't pass laws with more stringent regulations regarding those services sold in their state. The company chooses the state whose laws they want to comply with. "Returning power to the states" means removing federal laws which would supercede those of the least restrictive state's laws.

I agree the Rox need a another quality RH arm in the bullpen that can be trusted in high leverage situations, but they also need to seriously think about upgrading the catcher position (would be almost anyone other than Wolters) if the cost is reasonable.

Comment: Jenny Eggers was a truly gifted young woman. At the University of Oregon she was a Journalism student majoring in advertising and she was also a Clark Honors College student. She wrote a brilliant Honors College thesis comparing advertising in developing South American countries with advertising in the United States. She created her own model for how advertising should be approached in countries with developing markets. In addition to being an outstanding student, Jenny was so generous and kind that she brought grace to every situation she entered. She was committed, imaginative and disciplined—all qualities that assured her many successes. My thoughts and prayers are with Jenny's family during this time of unbearable loss.  
Ann Maxwell, School of Journalism and Communications faculty for Jenny's Clark Honors College Thesis.

Comment: Hiding history is shameful, explaining it is not. If monuments are "whitewashing" history, modify the explanations to more accurately reflect what happened.  However, I have seen examples of modern day "history buffs" who have not the slightest clue about the history they abhor or how historians work, nor the importance of accurate portrayals.  Very few people are totally good or totally evil.  They are people.  A thorough accounting of someone's actions and explanations of the times and environment in which they live is preferable to obliterating the memory of their actions.

The destruction of historical monuments, rather than clarifying and educating with them, is shameful and ridiculous.  There is a civil war museum that recently closed its doors because the city council members told them to hide any Confederate artifacts, insisting the story of the civil war could be adequately told without mention of or visual aids to the Confederacy.  What in heck happened to public education?

To get to health care in the private sector one would have to overcome the propaganda that still persists about Canada’s health care being superior and the US health care being something less. However all the US system needs is a Guaranteed Annual Income for the people who need help to convert the best medical system to the best health care system. 

There would be no increase in cost, in fact probably savings as the funds for health care, welfare and social housing are converted to the GAI. Certainly those who need help would now be living better, on the economy rather than in ghettoes, a plague of cities. Cities would not own housing.

Comment: A State lawyer who tells a Governor, or sometimes even a commissioner, something s/he doesn't want to hear puts his/her career on the line.   As a general matter, the formal, publicly expressed, opinion of the Attorney General or his/her Assistants is what the Governor wants it to be.   I'm not an advocate of an elected and thus independent, sorta', AG, but I do believe the State needs a Solicitor General who serves for a prescribed term and is only removable for cause to represent the State or challenge the State in litigation without political interference.   I've framed lots of conversations with State lawyers with, "I didn't call you to ask you what to do, I called you to tell you what I was going to do and ask you how to make it legal.   State lawyers have a lot of trouble distinguishing between law and policy.

Comment: I was attacked as a young girl by a dog and bitten in the face so I have a fear of dogs running straight for me.  In the wonderful last frontier of ours a lot of people just don't get why they can't let their animals run free.  I have dogs I want them to run free, get exercise, be a dog but in a community where there are lots of people or on trails where there are kids and other hikers you have to have control of your dogs.  When I hike or go on the trails with my dogs, I watch for approaching hikers and command my dogs to walk next to me while passing hikers.  I don't allow them to approach strangers.  Not everyone loves dogs.  Not everyone likes when dogs run up to them even if they appear friendly.  Here in the neighborhood I live...I can not walk the neighborhood because too many dog owners allow their dogs out unsupervised.  If you can not seriously control your dog by voice then keep them leased or move to a rural area where you just won't run into people.

Comment: I question your version of history, but here is something more pragmatic:
http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/04/06/native-hawaiian-population/
Our native population--those who claim Koko--has bounced back. Now what? Who will unify our direction forward? Will looking to the past in bitterness and anger really be productive? Or, is perpetuating bitterness an end in itself for those who offer it? Our way forward is through the `aina, touching it, working it, shaping it via pono. The Western World was our Pandora's Box, and we opened it. It was not unleashed upon us entirely without consent, from the introduction of venereal disease, to the introduction of lawyers, guns and money, liquor and tobacco, drugs and politics, we indulged. The question then remains, "So, now what?"
Looking backward is not unimportant. But it is of secondary import.
So, now what?

Comment: Ah yes, we call it "reading from the Big Book of Fish Pimp Lies."

Cue the Information Age, and one or two outfits owned and overseen by fishers, who have been, on occasion, able to post a price that keeps the big guys honest.  It didn't really happen last year---But I don't see any sockeye on the shelves anymore, and the fiscal year isn't over...

By the way, Bristol Bay is wide open for cash buyers, and fuel prices are as low as they're going to get.  I know significant numbers of refrigerated boats who would be willing to sell high quality fish to anyone willing to make the trip---And it doesn't sound like they'll have to work too hard to beat the price.  In mid June you could put up a nice stock of the best king salmon on the planet in the Nushagak, and in early July fill your boat with the kind of first-rate quality sockeye a new refrigerated fleet has been producing.

You get what you pay for when it comes to "County" versus "City" living.

Comment: I first saw Homer in 1978. Peaceful little hamlet by the sea, that had and still has a strong spirit of welcoming all because we are all different and we all need each other. That is the endurance of Plymouth Colony from where I moved from, in order to survive we need each other. ( Plymouth Colony was only 1/2 the religious Pilgrims and they other 1/2 were secular colonists.)  I moved from Dutch Harbor to Homer in 1991. Homer lives up to it's history and purpose for being  here. Now, there are things in any community that happen and are not good . But the ideology has not left Homer and the vibe of we are all in this together has never left us. I go in town almost daily. No one talks politics in anyway that would end up in some silly fight after drawing some imaginary line in the sand. People still open doors for you and help you out of the market with your groceries. People laugh and joke a lot, and smile. And we try our best to be helpful to the visitors. We support these values.

Comment: There is at once a generational and cultural paradigm shift that maybe occurring here. By way of specific example, the cultural precepts of tofugu and ha'aha'a are remarkably similar and interrelated.

In America, we tend to be encouraged to show our individualist side, take initiative, tell people about our accomplishments, and stick out as much as possible from the rest of society. Conversely, in both Asian and Polynesian cultures their is priority to praise others, while looking much more critical and introspective to yourself, while upholding the culture’s traditional respect for humility. 

Sociologists hold this behavior crucial in maintaining harmonious interpersonal relations by a cultural intervention and amelioration for superfluous conflict. The right amount of modesty means assessing oneself on the harsh side with an eye toward stoic, self improvement. Moreover, in the intermediate and long term, this humility puts others at ease. Such is real aloha.

Auwe to Ms. Kent.....

Comment: Tom, 
I am very aware that there is only one federally recognized Indian Reservation in Alaska, I live 25 miles away from Metlakatla and have family with roots there. A month or so ago there was an article in the Dispatch about the State of Alaska and certain tribes/villages making an agreement where those tribes would handle, in tribal courts, certain low level criminal charges (misdemeanors) and to handle CINA  cases (child in need of aid cases). Tribes already have specific rights in CINA cases because of the ICWA law (Indian Child Welfare Act). In addition to that, two tribes recently applied for and received agreement for certain parcels of their land to be put into/under Federal Trust. That land will be under Federal/tribal jurisdiction. Currently, per PL 280, the Alaska tribes (except Metlakatla) do fall under State Laws but it is also true that ALL tribes in Alaska have certain recognized rights (such as ICWA), and maintain a government to government relationship with the Feds.

Comment: Regarding "recycling" old Christmas light strings.  It may make you feel good.  But read Adam Minter's "Junkyard Planet" to find out how it is recycled.  It will be sent to China where it will be burned in an open pit to remove the plastic from the copper.  And most of the peasants doing this dirty work will die from cancer brought on from years of breathing the fumes of burning plastic.  Besides people dying, it doesn't do much good for air quality either.  So you don't actually "recycle" old Christmas lights here in the US.  You just outsource your pollution to another part of the world.  And once the pollution is created and people die, then the copper is recycled to make more Christmas lights that folks in the US will buy.  And the cycle continues.
